prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 12CO(7-6) and [CI](2-1)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Spectral line observation of the lines CO(7-6) and [CI](2-1) in Band 4. Observing in one baseband split into two spectral windows.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The correlator set-up was chosen on the basis of the arguments made in the first justification. We used a line width of dV = 385 km/s for the calculations of all spectral lines for a 3 sigma detection using 20 km/s channels. For this science goal, we chose the correlator set-up and split it into two equal spectral windows (one for each line) with bandwidths of 937.5 MHz and ~2.067 km/s channels. Averaging by a factor of ~9.6 would still give us our required 20 km/s bins.

The science focus of the proposal is the accurate measurement of line fluxes, widths, and ratios. Therefore, we can make use of the most compact configuration (C36-1), for which weather demands and concerns about resolving out flux are minimized. Based on our SMA observations , our target is ~7.3". The most compact configuration produces a naturally weighted beam of ~2.5" at 101.277 GHz. For this beam size we expect emission across ~7.1 beams for both the CO(7-6) and [CI](2-1) lines.

With LMT/RSR CO(5-4) and CO(4-3) detections for ACT J0253 already in hand, we use these lines to get estimates of other integrated line fluxes. CO(5-4) and CO(4-3) are found to have integrated line fluxes of S(CO)dV = 5.2 Jy km/s (dV= 407 km/s) and S(CO)dV = 6.9 Jy km/s (dV = 370 km/s), and we opted to use an intermediate line width of dV= 385 km/s for all calculations and base time requests on a desired 20 km/s spectral resolution allow for detailed velocity profile companions. We expect the Line/CO(5-4) and the Line/CO(4-3) line ratios for ACT J2053 to be similar to those of other high-z star forming galaxies (e.g., SMM J2132-0102). We therefore scaled the integrated line fluxes with the line ratios presented in Danielson et al. (2011) and used the most conservative line flux ratio to scale the flux (choosing between Line/CO(5-4) and Line/CO(4-3)). To estimate CO(7-6) and [CI], the Line/CO(5-4) ratio measured by Danielson et al. (2011) and yields predictions of 3.5 Jy km/s and 4.5 Jy km/s, respectively. We note that we would like to observe this set of lines for 1.64 hours because [CI] being the weaker line needs slightly more integration time for a 3 sigma detection in a 20 km/s channel.

The correlator set-up was chosen on the basis of the arguments made in the first justification. We used a line width of dV = 385 km/s for the calculations of all spectral lines for a 3 sigma detection using a 40 km/s channel width. For this science goal, we chose the correlator set-up with a bandwidth of 1875 MHz and 1.808 km/s channels. Averaging by a factor of ~22 would still give us our required 40 km/s bins.

The science focus of the proposal is the accurate measurement of line fluxes, widths, and ratios. Therefore, we can make use of the most compact configuration (C36-1), for which weather demands and concerns about resolving out flux are minimized. Based on our SMA observations , our target is ~7.3". The most compact configuration produces a naturally weighted beam of ~2.5" at 162.0035 GHz. For this beam size we expect emission across ~7.1 beams for CO(8-7).

With LMT/RSR CO(5-4) and CO(4-3) detections for ACT J0253 already in hand, we use these lines to get estimates of other integrated line fluxes. CO(5-4) and CO(4-3) are found to have integrated line fluxes of S(CO)dV = 5.2 Jy km/s (dV= 407 km/s) and S(CO)dV = 6.9 Jy km/s (dV = 370 km/s), and we opted to use an intermediate line width of dV= 385 km/s for all calculations and base time requests on a desired 20 km/s spectral resolution allow for detailed velocity profile companions. We expect the Line/CO(5-4) and the Line/CO(4-3) line ratios for ACT J2053 to be similar to those of other high-z star forming galaxies (e.g., SMM J2132-0102). We therefore scaled the integrated line fluxes with the line ratios presented in Danielson et al. (2011) and used the most conservative line flux ratio to scale the flux (choosing between Line/CO(5-4) and Line/CO(4-3)).To estimate CO(8-7), the CO(8-7)/CO(4-3) ratio measured by Danielson et al. (2011) is most conservative and yields a prediction of 2.44 Jy km/s. We note that we would like to observe this line for 1.23 hours for a 3 sigma detection in a 40 km/s channel.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 12CO(5-4) and [CI](1-0)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observations of the CO(5-4) and [CI](1-0) lines in Band 3. Each line is to be observed in a different baseband. In order to not go over the data rate we had to do spectral averaging by a factor of two.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The correlator set-up was chosen on the basis of the arguments made in the first justification. We used a line width of dV = 385 km/s for the calculations of all spectral lines for a 3 sigma detection using 20 km/s channels. For this science goal, we chose to use to one side band for each line due to the natural frequency separation between both lines. Each baseband was set up with 1875 MHz of bandwidth and to stay under the excessive data limit we did spectral averaging by a factor of 2. With the spectral averaging, Basebands 1 and 2 have a channel size of 3.344 km/s and 3.827 km/s, respectively. To achieve our desired 20 km/s channel width, we can average Baseband 1 by a factor of ~6 and Baseband 2 by a factor of ~5 (a factor of ~5 would suffice for both if needed).

The science focus of the proposal is the accurate measurement of line fluxes, widths, and ratios. Therefore, we can make use of the most compact configuration (C36-1), for which weather demands and concerns about resolving out flux are minimized. Based on our SMA observations, our target is ~7.3". The most compact configuration produces a naturally weighted beam of ~3.5" at 101.277 GHz (Band 4). For this beam size we expect emission across ~3.6 beams for both the CO(5-4) and [CI](1-0) lines.

With LMT/RSR CO(5-4) and CO(4-3) detections for ACT J0253 already in hand, we use these lines to get estimates of other integrated line fluxes. CO(5-4) and CO(4-3) are found to have integrated line fluxes of S(CO)dV = 5.2 Jy km/s (dV= 407 km/s) and S(CO)dV = 6.9 Jy km/s (dV = 370 km/s), and we opted to use an intermediate line width of dV= 385 km/s for all calculations and base time requests on a desired 20 km/s spectral resolution allow for detailed velocity profile companions. We expect the Line/CO(5-4) and the Line/CO(4-3) line ratios for ACT J2053 to be similar to those of other high-z star forming galaxies (e.g., SMM J2132-0102). We therefore scaled the integrated line fluxes with the line ratios presented in Danielson et al. (2011) and used the most conservative line flux ratio to scale the flux (choosing between Line/CO(5-4) and Line/CO(4-3)). We used the measured flux of 5.2 Jy km/s by our group with the LMT/RSR. To estimate the [CI](1-0) integrated flux, the line ratio [CI](1-0)/CO(4-3) measured by Spilker et al. (2014) is most conservative and yielded a prediction of 1.61 Jy km/s. We note that we would like to observe this set of lines for 1.01 hours because [CI](1-0) being the weaker line needs more integration time for a 3 sigma detection in a 20 km/s channel.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: [CII] fine structure line
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observation of [CII] line in Band 7. An important line to observe due to ratio comparisons that can be be made with other studies.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The correlator set-up was chosen on the basis of the arguments made in the first justification. We used a line width of dV = 385 km/s for the calculations of all spectral lines for a 3 sigma detection using a 20 km/s channel width. For this science goal, we chose the correlator set-up with a bandwidth of 1875 MHz and 0.877 km/s channels. Averaging by a factor of ~22.8 would still give us our required 20 km/s bins.

The science focus of the proposal is the accurate measurement of line fluxes, widths, and ratios. Therefore, we can make use of the most compact configuration (C36-1), for which weather demands and concerns about resolving out flux are minimized. Based on our SMA observations, our target is ~7.3". The most compact configuration produces a naturally weighted beam of ~1.5" at 335.68 GHz. For this beam size we expect emission across ~19.7 beams for [CII].

With LMT/RSR CO(5-4) and CO(4-3) detections for ACT J0253 already in hand, we use these lines to get estimates of other integrated line fluxes. CO(5-4) and CO(4-3) are found to have integrated line fluxes of S(CO)dV = 5.2 Jy km/s (dV= 407 km/s) and S(CO)dV = 6.9 Jy km/s (dV = 370 km/s), and we opted to use an intermediate line width of dV= 385 km/s for all calculations and base time requests on a desired 20 km/s spectral resolution allow for detailed velocity profile companions. We expect the Line/CO(5-4) and the Line/CO(4-3) line ratios for ACT J2053 to be similar to those of other high-z star forming galaxies (e.g., SMM J2132-0102). We therefore scaled the integrated line fluxes with the line ratios presented in Danielson et al. (2011) and used the most conservative line flux ratio to scale the flux (choosing between Line/CO(5-4) and Line/CO(4-3)).To estimate [CII], the [CII]/CO(5-4) ratio measured by Danielson et al. (2011) is most conservative and yields a prediction of 236.36 km/s. We note that we would like to observe this line for ~32 minutes for a 3 sigma detection in a 20 km/s channel.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: [OI] fine structure line
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observation of the [OI] fine structure line in Band 7.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The correlator set-up was chosen on the basis of the arguments made in the first justification. We used a line width of dV = 385 km/s for the calculations of all spectral lines for a 3 sigma detection using a 20 km/s channel width. For this science goal, we chose the correlator set-up with a bandwidth of 1875 MHz and 0.809 km/s channels. Averaging by a factor of ~24.7 would still give us our required 20 km/s bins.

The science focus of the proposal is the accurate measurement of line fluxes, widths, and ratios. Therefore, we can make use of the most compact configuration (C36-1), for which weather demands and concerns about resolving out flux are minimized. Based on our SMA observations, our target is ~7.3". The most compact configuration produces a naturally weighted beam of ~1.5" at 362.99 GHz. For this beam size we expect emission across ~19.7 beams for [OI].

With LMT/RSR CO(5-4) and CO(4-3) detections for ACT J0253 already in hand, we use these lines to get estimates of other integrated line fluxes. CO(5-4) and CO(4-3) are found to have integrated line fluxes of S(CO)dV = 5.2 Jy km/s (dV= 407 km/s) and S(CO)dV = 6.9 Jy km/s (dV = 370 km/s), and we opted to use an intermediate line width of dV= 385 km/s for all calculations and base time requests on a desired 20 km/s spectral resolution allow for detailed velocity profile companions. We expect the Line/CO(5-4) and the Line/CO(4-3) line ratios for ACT J2053 to be similar to those of other high-z star forming galaxies (e.g., SMM J2132-0102). We therefore scaled the integrated line fluxes with the line ratios presented in Danielson et al. (2011) and used the most conservative line flux ratio to scale the flux (choosing between Line/CO(5-4) and Line/CO(4-3)).To estimate [OI], the [OI]/CO(5-4) ratio measured by Danielson et al. (2011) is most conservative and yields a prediction of 172.4 Jy km/s. We note that we would like to observe this line for ~32 minutes for a 3 sigma detection in a 20 km/s channel.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: [NII] 204 um line
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observation of the [NII] fine structure line in Band 7.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The correlator set-up was chosen on the basis of the arguments made in the first justification. We used a line width of dV = 385 km/s for the calculations of all spectral lines for a 3 sigma detection using a 20 km/s channel width. For this science goal, we chose the correlator set-up with a bandwidth of 1875 MHz and 1.141 km/s channels. Averaging by a factor of ~17.5 would still give us our required 20 km/s bins.

The science focus of the proposal is the accurate measurement of line fluxes, widths, and ratios. Therefore, we can make use of the most compact configuration (C36-1), for which weather demands and concerns about resolving out flux are minimized. Based on our SMA observations, our target is ~7.3". The most compact configuration produces a naturally weighted beam of ~1.75" at 257.19 GHz. For this beam size we expect emission across ~14.5 beams for [NII].

With LMT/RSR CO(5-4) and CO(4-3) detections for ACT J0253 already in hand, we use these lines to get estimates of other integrated line fluxes. CO(5-4) and CO(4-3) are found to have integrated line fluxes of S(CO)dV = 5.2 Jy km/s (dV= 407 km/s) and S(CO)dV = 6.9 Jy km/s (dV = 370 km/s), and we opted to use an intermediate line width of dV= 385 km/s for all calculations and base time requests on a desired 20 km/s spectral resolution allow for detailed velocity profile companions. We expect the Line/CO(5-4) and the Line/CO(4-3) line ratios for ACT J2053 to be similar to those of other high-z star forming galaxies (e.g., SMM J2132-0102). We therefore scaled the integrated line fluxes with the line ratios presented in Danielson et al. (2011) and used the most conservative line flux ratio to scale the flux (choosing between Line/CO(5-4) and Line/CO(4-3)).The [NII] line was unique case because we had to combine ratios from two different studies. We used the [CII]/CO(5-4)ratio (most conservative) from Danielson et al. (2011) and the [NII]/[CII] from De Breuck et al. (2014) to estimate the line integrated flux of [NII] for ACTJ0253 and estimated it to be 20.1 Jy km/s.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: A new population of high-$z$ dusty star-forming galaxies (DSFGs) has recently been discovered by the Atacama Cosmology Telescope (ACT) 470 deg^2 survey. This survey is of great interest because compared to other studies, e.g., of the populations typically detected by the Herschel Space Observatory, we expect the redshift distribution of this population to be higher based on their wavelength selection. Similar to surveys with \textit{Herschel} and the South Pole Telescope (SPT), we also expect these objects to be strongly lensed by foreground structure. We propose multi-line spectral observations with ALMA on ACT J0253-0003, the highest redshift object in our sample with confirmed z= 4.6940 +/- 0.0005, to study in detail the physical conditions in a vigorously star-forming galaxy at a very early cosmic time, in order to further our understanding of massive galaxy formation.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: ALMA Continuum Imaging of ACT DSFGs, Resolved CO Mapping of lensed ACT DSFGS, An efficient redshift search for ACT star-forming galaxies
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
